title: How to Reset Your iPhone's Network Settings to Factory Defaults

steps.title: Back up your device (optional).
steps.content: Back up your device (optional). While resetting your network settings won't delete any of your data, you may want to back up your device if you think you might want to easily return to your old network settings.

steps.title: Open the Settings app.
steps.content: Open the Settings app. The Settings app is in your device's dock by default. It has a silver icon with gears on it.

steps.title: Tap General.
steps.content: Tap General . This option is near the top of the Settings menu. It has a gray icon with a white gear on it (similar to the Settings icon).

steps.title: Tap Transfer or Reset iPhone.
steps.content: Tap Transfer or Reset iPhone . This option is at the bottom of the General menu, so you'll need to scroll down to see it. It has a gray icon with a white circular arrow on it. If you're on an iPad, the option will say Transfer or Reset iPad instead.

steps.title: Choose Reset.
steps.content: Choose Reset . It's the top option.

steps.title: Tap Reset Network Settings.
steps.content: Tap Reset Network Settings . It's the second option on the list.

steps.title: Enter your passcode, if requested.
steps.content: Enter your passcode, if requested. If you don't have a passcode, you can skip this step.

steps.title: Tap Reset Network Settings at the bottom of the screen.
steps.content: Tap Reset Network Settings at the bottom of the screen. Once you tap this button, all of the network connections on your device will be removed, and your network settings will be reset to factory defaults. This includes Wi-Fi networks, any custom cellular settings, and VPN or APN settings. [1] X Research source Allow your phone to finish resetting your network settings before turning off your device.
